snippet.textDisplay:
Just to raise an observation:. After Jeanne at the beginning of the clip was a great voice in support of raising awarenesses that racism against Asian-Americans exists!, and, AMERICAN RACISM CAN BE WHITE-ON-ASIAN AND BLACK-ON-ASIAN (people only have wanted to recognize ASIAN-ON-BLACK),....
There were two subtle "sweeps-under-the-rug."
1. When Loni said, I didn't see an Asian man, I saw my grandfather. Even though in part she was trying to underscore being race-blind to his Asianness, this highlighted the elder abuse aspect and diverted away from the antiAsian reality what had just been highlighted.
2. Amanda did the same thing when she at the end listed groups and referred to the clip as elder abuse, not racism when IT WAS RACISM AND IT WAS HIS ASIANNESS THEY WERE COMING DOWN ON HIM FOR AND SAID THEY HATED.

snippet.textDisplay: Can someone shut the mouth of that girl next to Jeannie? If there's ANY chance for a person to have this much of public appearance and have her/his voice heard, you want to hear words that would not encapsulate the main issue again in a cutter wrap. Loni was totally right in saying this is someone's grandfather instead of just an asian person being molested, and then we have miss "I'm too cute but you're still asian and I'm still black" ladie on the round table? GET OUT, les estoy hablando desde Bogotá Colombia, I've been outside my country only one time and it was enough to understand the impact that a tv personality can do, this whole section of the show was a huge problem just passing by someone's (her) shoulders and not leaving a clear mark on what people should do. Black people, yes, I'm aware you might have suffered throughout the years and have stories of awful kind to share and learn from, but if you guys are preaching love and change, her words were not close to lead a movement of consciousness and tolerance. I love the show, I love your ladies, but for the longest time I have struggled with her opinions, and I don't usually participate in this community but this topic hit hard because I've felt multiple times and I myself consider that I use my life to say nothing else but words that would route anyone or anything wherever I go to a better place. I don't think that ladie has a quality of speech to be sitting so frequently, it's sad and disappointing to see how Jeannie is clearly professional yet so affected while she explained the topic and just get a pad on the back. This is very upsetting to me. But hey, I'm on the other side of America, I just really hope that despite all the careless moments during this show, there would be a space to remember how deep and important things were and not how cute you were looking while you just displayed your answer on the table.

snippet.textDisplay: My bf is latino, although American. When we first started dating, he always thought my demand for respect and equality from the world was kind of "radical" (I'm black), because unbeknownst to him, he was raised to generally accept racism towards him because it makes you a "good minority" to be agreeable and "grateful " for being here. Whereas being African American, I feel we (justifiably) are more concious and demanding of our rights because we have been here for generations, in many cases longer than our white counterparts. It was an educational experience for the both of us, because I didn't know that there's people who didn't speak up, and he didn't know that he had the right to do so. After 5 years of being together, we're both pretty outspoken about equality.

snippet.textDisplay: I actually disagree with what Amanda was saying @ 3:13... While I think that every body should consider it a duty and a personal responsibility to stand up to injustices they see or know about - jumping into such grotesque situations as this was and recording it as a means of gaining some sort of clout - isn't a very fair or correct insinuation to make. This horrifying video ended up going viral - and it rightfully shocked and incensed people all over the world. Furthermore, it shined a light onto the acrimonious resentment that has been brewing between the black and asian communities - which despite what Amanda might think - it is not something that everyone knows about. Also footage like this will help in aiding the proper authorities with being able to identify the monsters who need to be held responsible for their despicable acts. All I am trying to say is that, if all you are able to do is take a video of the atrocities of an injustice that you happen to be a witness of, then you are doing a big part in helping to stand up to injustice, and I think that you are providing a good and a thank-worthy service.
